block-definition.comment: Reports a new list whose items are the same as in the input list, except that if two or more equal items appear in the input list, only the last one is kept in the result.

Reports a sorted version of the list in its first input slot, using the comparison function in the second input slot. For a list of numbers, using < as the comparison function will sort from low to high; using > will sort from high to low.

The second input is an "association list," a list of two-item lists. Each of those smaller lists has a "key" as its first item and a "value" as its second. ASSOC reports the first key-value pair in the association list whose key matches the first input.

This block carries out the given script for each item of the given list, like the primitive FOR EACH. What's different is that it provides the # variable, which will contain the item number in the list of each item in turn, 1 while processing item 1, and so on.
Takes a (possibly deep) list as input, and reports a human-readable text form of the list (namely, Lisp notation). Will not work on circular lists.

SENTENCE is the main constructor for sentences, represented as lists of words. It takes zero or more inputs, each of which can be either a list or a text string. If a list, the input is assumed to be a list of words. If a text string, it is converted to a list of words using SENTENCE→LIST. Then all the lists of words are appended to form a new list of words. If the inputs are lists of lists rather than lists of words, SENTENCE, like APPEND, does only one level of flattening, reporting a list of all the items of all the input lists.

ZIP takes any number of lists as inputs. The lists should all be the same length. ZIP reports a list of lists in which the first item is a list of all the first items, the second item is a list of all the second items, etc. Viewing the inputs as the rows of a matrix, ZIP reports its transpose.
The identity function reports its input.

Takes as input a function of N inputs and N lists. The function is called with item 1 of all the lists as its inputs, with item 2 of all the lists as its inputs, and so on. (The lists should all be the same length.)
Takes a sentence in text string form and reports the sentence as a list of its words.
block-definition.translations: de:Satz $arrowRight Liste _ ca:frase $arrowRight llista _ es:frase $arrowRight lista _ fr:phrase $arrowRight liste _ pt:uma lista com as palavras da frase _

block-definition.comment: Reports the part of the first string up to the first instance of the second string inside it. If the second string isn't found, reports the entire first string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:part del text _ anterior a _

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input string starting after the first occurrence of the second string. If the second string isn't found in the first string, reports an empty string.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ depois de _ ca:part del text _ posterior a _

custom-block.s: substring of %txt from position %n to position %n inclusive

block-definition.comment: Reports the character position (starting from 1) of the beginning of the first input string inside the second input string. If it's not found, reports 0.
block-definition.translations: pt:a posição de _ em _ ca:posició de _ en _

block-definition.comment: If input is TRUE, comparisons made by functions in the string library will be case-independent (so "FOO" = "foo"). This is the default. If input is FALSE, comparisons will be exact.
block-definition.translations: pt:altera comparações ignorando distinção minúsculas/maiúsculas para _ ca:ignora la diferenciació de majúscules _

block-definition.s: substring of %'str' from position %'start' to position %'end' inclusive
block-definition.comment: Reports the portion of the first input (string) starting at the position given by the second input (counting from 1, like LETTER n OF) and ending at the position given by the third input (also counting from 1). If the third input is empty, reports the portion from the first position to the end of the string. If a position number is negative, counts from the end backward, so -1 is the last character, -2 is the next to last, etc.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ entre as posições _ e _ , inclusive ca:part del text _ des de la posició _ fins _

block-definition.comment: Reports True if the first input string contains the second input string, otherwise false. Comparison is case-independent by default; use USE CASE-INDEPENDENT COMPARISONS to change that.
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ antes de _ ca:text _ conté _ ?

block-definition.comment: Reports the input text with lower case letters instead of capital letters in the input. Uses the user's locale's rules for case conversion.
reports the MD5 hash of the text

block.comment: reverse byte order of each 32 bit row

custom-block.s: reverse byte order of %n assuming %n bytes length
reverse byte order of %n assuming %n bytes length
reverse byte order of %n assuming %n bytes length
reverse byte order of %n assuming %n bytes length
reverse byte order of %n assuming %n bytes length

block-definition.comment: 1st item is MSB
original code by Glen Bull Modified to remove library dependancy and reverse order of digits - MSB is item 1 of the list

Combined text/list reporter Reports the portion of the first input starting at the position given by the second input and ending at the position given by the third input. If the third input is empty, reports the portion from the first position to the end of the string. If a position number is negative, counts from the end backward, so -1 is the last character/item, -2 is the next to last, etc. If processed start value > processed end value then the result will be in reported in reverse order Note: If the processed values lie outside the range of 1 to length of item, then an empty value or empty list will be returned. 17Sep2022 Tidy up 05Sep2022 range checking behaviour altered 01Sep2022 V1.2.0 Align algorthim with library substring 27Aug2022 V1.1.1 bug-fix length handling
block-definition.translations: pt:o texto de _ entre as posições _ e _ , inclusive ca:part del text _ des de la posició _ fins _

block-definition.s: reverse byte order of %'n' assuming %'bytes' bytes length
block-definition.comment: reverses the byte order of a number If the input number is prefixed by 0b or 0x, then the ouput will also be prefixed
converts a number to its binary representation with or without a 0b prefix If length is blank or 0, then it will create it to the minimum length required Does not currently handle negative numbers

convert a positive number into its hexadecimal representation, with or without a 0x prefix If the length is empty or zero, the result will be as short as possible. Otherwise it will be truncated or padded with leading zeros to acheive the length required

input.options: 1 (nibble) =1 2 (byte) =2 4 (2 bytes or 16 bits) =4 8 (4 bytes or 32 bits) =8

block-definition.comment: rotates the items in a list value can be negative to rotate the other way
If search item is a list, then returns index of search list within main list Reports zero if not found If not a list, behaves as per normal index of reporter 07Sep2022 V1.0.0
Heap's algorithm https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heap%27s_algorithm

This is a breakpoint block, to be used in debugging. The Boolean input specifies the condition under which the program should pause. (Use True for an unconditional breakpoint.) The intent is that the script should have SHOW VARIABLE blocks for the process's local variables. After the pause, this block automatically hides all temporary variables.
block-definition.translations: de:falls _ dann _ und pause $pause-1-255-220-0 ca:si _ fes _ i atura-ho tot $pause-1-255-220-0 es:si _ haz _ y páralo todo $pause-1-255-220-0 fr:si _ faire _ et mettre tout en pause $pause-1-255-220-0 pt:se _ , então _ e faz pausa em tudo $pause-1-255-220-0

block-definition.comment: This block does nothing. Use it when you are calling a reporter for its side effect and don't care about its return value.
Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) n times where the three input slots are n, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f to represent how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado de _ invocações em cascata de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada _ vegades _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Call f(f(f(...(f(x))))) until condition is true, where the three input slots are condition, f, and x from left to right. The # variable can be used inside f or condition to indicate how many times f has been called.
block-definition.translations: pt:o resultado da invocação em cascata até que _ de _ com argumento inicial _ _ ca:en cascada fins _ _ _ _

block-definition.comment: Returns the function x↦f(g(x)) where f and g are the two inputs.
Like the built-in REPEAT UNTIL block, except that the ending condition is not tested until the script has been run the first time. So the script is run at least once.
Run the script repeatedly, as long as the given condition is true. Runs the script at least once before testing the condition.

Runs the script repeatedly, as long as the condition is true. Tests the condition before the first time the script is run. Like the built in REPEAT UNTIL except that in this block the condition must be true, not false.

Runs the script the specified number of times, like the built-in REPEAT block, but this one provides the # variable that can be used inside the script. Try REPEAT (200) MOVE (#) STEPS RIGHT 92 with the pen down.

The primitive FOR block uses an implicit step of ±1 depending on which of the starting and ending values is larger. This version allows you to provide an explicit step value. If the sign of the step input is incompatible with the ordering of the starting and ending values, the script will not be run at all.
block-definition.translations: pt:para _ de _ com passo _ a _ _ $loop-0.7 ca:per _ = _ incrementant _ fins _ _

block-definition.comment: Provides LOOP as a function of one input that runs the body of the LET with A set to the function input, so the body can run itself recursively. See COPY block in Variables for an example of use.
block-definition.translations: pt:tendo _ o valor inicial _ , executa _ definido como _ ca:fes que _ sigui _ al _ _

block-definition.comment: The inputs are a starting value and one or more monadic functions. The first function is called with the starting value as its input. The second function is called with the value reported by the first function as its input, and so on. PIPE reports the value reported by the last function. PIPE provides an alternative notation for function composition instead of the usual nesting. nested acronym: report (combine (keep items (capital-letter? ( )) from (map (letter (1) of ( )) over (sentence→list (phrase)))) using (join ( ) ( ))) piped acronym: report (pipe (phrase) → (sentence→list ( )) (map (letter (1) of ( )) over ( )) (keep items (capital-letter? ( )) from ( )) (combine ( ) using (join ( ) ( ))) Some people find PIPE easier to read because the functions are called in the same order in which you read them, whereas in nested composition the innermost function is called first.

splits text by several seperators Very useful for Advent of Code puzzle imput parsing but could be useful elsewhere If using on single line of text to produce a single 1 deminonal list - then feed output into flatten

inputs.input: A long,complicated line: like this one

block-definition.comment: report of the possible subsets of a list e.g [1,2,3] -> [[1],[2],[1,2],[3],[1,3],[2,3],[1,2,3]]

block-definition.s: %'#' for each %'item' of all subsets of %'data' %'action'
block-definition.comment: iterate over all the possible subsets of a list
return all iindices of the search item in the list

This block creates new variables on the selected scope: global (for all sprites), sprite (for this sprite only) or script (only for that blocks stack) with the names given (in 'names' list). If there is already a variable with that name in that scope, it does nothing: no errors and no overwrites.
block-definition.translations: pt:cria as variáveis _ _ ca:crea les _ variables _ es:crear las _ variables _ de:erstellen _ var _

block-definition.comment: This block deletes all the variables with the names given (inside input list). Each name will make only one variable deletion, and this will be the variable found following the scope order: 'script' -> 'sprite' -> 'global'. If we have a "testing" sprite variable and also a "testing" global one, deleting "testing" will delete only the sprite one (Yes! we can also do "delete var (testing, testing)" to delete both. If one variable does not exists (in any scope) an error happens, stopping block action in that point. You can check it before with the "does var (name) exists?"block.
block-definition.translations: pt:remove as variáveis _ ca:esborra les variables _ es:borrar variables _ de:löschen var _

block-definition.comment: This block sets the given value (last input) to the variable named with the name givent (var input). It looks for that variable following the scope order 'script' -> 'sprite' -> 'global' (the first match it finds). If that variable does not exist (in any scope) an error happens, stopping their script. You can check it before using the "does var (name) exists?" block.
block-definition.translations: ca:assigna a _ el valor _ es:asignar a _ el valor _ pt:altera _ para _ de:setze var _ auf _

block-definition.comment: This block reports the value of the variable with the name given. It looks for that variable following the scope order 'script' -> 'sprite' -> 'global' (the first match it finds). If that variable does not exist (in any scope) an error happens, stopping their script. You can check it before using the "does var (name) exists?" block.
This block reports "true" if there is a variable with this given name (input slot) in that context. It can be a global, sprite or script variable. Otherwise it reports "false".
block-definition.translations: pt:a variável _ existe ca:existeix la variable _ ? es:existe la variable _ ? de:existiert var _ ?

block-definition.comment: This block turns on (show) the watcher view on stage (if it was not already activated) of the variable with the given name (slot input). It can only access to the closest variable scope (if there different variables with the same name in different scopes) following the order 'script' -> 'sprite' -> 'global'. No errors if that variable does not exist.
block-definition.translations: ca:mostra la variable _ es:mostrar variable _ pt:mostra a variável _ de:zeige var _

block-definition.comment: This block turns off (hide) the watcher view on stage (if it was not already activated) of the variable with the given name (slot input). It can only access to the closest variable scope (if there different variables with the same name in different scopes) following the order 'script' -> 'sprite' -> 'global'. No errors if that variable does not exist.
block-definition.translations: ca:amaga la variable _ es:esconder variable _ pt:esconde a variável _ de:verstecke var _

block-definition.comment: find all factors of a number
when padding selected, instead of repeating source list values- use empty cells instead V1.0.1 Allow 1st dimension to be zero

inputs.input: defaultdefault pad with empty cells no repeat of cells

block.comment: sometimes 1st item is blank and sometime zero hence this <1 check

block-definition.comment: remove empty items from a list
